passage: While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes: • Claude Shannon was an American mathematician and electrical engineer. • He is known as the 'father of information theory' for his groundbreaking work in the field. • Shannon's 1948 paper, 'A Mathematical Theory of Communication,' laid the foundation for modern digital communication and data compression. • Shannon also made significant contributions to cryptography during World War II.
question: Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to explain Claude Shannon's impact on the field of information theory?

choices.A: Claude Shannon, an American mathematician, is known for his work in electrical engineering.
choices.B: Claude Shannon, known as the 'father of information theory,' laid the foundation for modern digital communication with his 1948 paper.
choices.C: Claude Shannon contributed to cryptography during World War II and was an electrical engineer.
choices.D: Claude Shannon's work in information theory was influential, but he also made contributions to cryptography and electrical engineering.

explanation: B: 'Claude Shannon, known as the 'father of information theory,' laid the foundation for modern digital communication with his 1948 paper.' is the correct answer because it effectively explains Shannon's impact on the field of information theory by mentioning his groundbreaking work and its significance.
distractor_explanation: 'Claude Shannon, an American mathematician, is known for his work in electrical engineering.' is incorrect because it does not mention Shannon's impact on information theory.
'Claude Shannon contributed to cryptography during World War II and was an electrical engineer.' is incorrect because it does not mention his groundbreaking work in information theory.

'Claude Shannon's work in information theory was influential, but he also made contributions to cryptography and electrical engineering.' is incorrect because it does not effectively highlight the significance of his work in information theory.
